item.title: Our Book Critics on Their Year in Reading
item.description: Alexandra Jacobs, Jennifer Szalai and Dwight Garner look back at the books that, as Jacobs writes, “bonked me on the head this year.”

item.title: How Matt Dinniman’s ‘Dungeon Crawler Carl’ Became a Blockbuster
item.description: Matt Dinniman introduced his series about an alien reality TV show free on the web. But readers ate up the goofy humor, now to the tune of 6 million books sold.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Dolly Faibyshev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matt Dinniman signing books at New York Comic Con this fall.

item.title: The 10 Best Books of 2025
item.description: The staff of The New York Times Book Review choose the year’s top fiction and nonfiction.
item.category: The Loneliness of Sonia and Sunny (Book)
There Is No Place for Us: Working and Homeless in America (Book)
Mother Emanuel: Two Centuries of Race, Resistance, and Forgiveness in One Charleston Church (Book)
A Marriage at Sea: A True Story of Love, Obsession, and Shipwreck (Book)
Wild Thing: A Life of Paul Gauguin (Book)

item.title: 100 Notable Books of 2025
item.description: Here is the standout fiction and nonfiction of the year, selected by the staff of The New York Times Book Review.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times Books Staff

item.title: The Best Romance Books of 2025
item.description: Here are the books our columnist loved the most this year.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Waite

item.title: The Best Historical Fiction of 2025
item.description: Our columnist picks the year’s outstanding books.
item.dc:creator: Alida Becker

item.title: The Best Thriller Books of 2025
item.description: Our columnist on the books that wowed her this year.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall

item.title: Our Critics Look Back on Their Year in Reading
item.description: It’s been a good one. Dwight Garner, Alexandra Jacobs and Jennifer Szalai discuss the books that have stayed with them.
item.category: 38 Londres Street: On Impunity, Pinochet in England, and a Nazi in Patagonia (Book)
Class Clown: The Memoirs of a Professional Wiseass: How I Went 77 Years Without Growing Up (Book)
Electric Spark: The Enigma of Dame Muriel (Book)
Flagrant, Self-Destructive Gestures: A Biography of Denis Johnson (Book)
The Loneliness of Sonia and Sunny (Book)
Troublemaker: The Fierce, Unruly Life of Jessica Mitford (Book)
When All the Men Wore Hats: Susan Cheever on the Stories of John Cheever (Book)
When the Going Was Good: An Editor's Adventures During the Last Golden Age of Magazines (Book)
Wild Thing: A Life of Paul Gauguin (Book)

item.title: Joanna Trollope, Popular British Author, Dies at 82
item.description: Her books, many of which were best sellers, often described empty marriages, love affairs (with tasteful sex) and heroic clergymen.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: Joanna Trollope after she was made a Commander of the Order of the British Empire in 2019.

item.title: The Best Poetry of 2025
item.description: Here are the year’s most notable collections of verse as chosen by our poetry columnist.
item.dc:creator: Elisa Gabbert
item.category: Gaza: The Poem Said Its Piece (Book)

item.title: The Best Graphic Novels of 2025
item.description: A candy-colored story collection, sisters who lust after Hitler and harrowing reportage from a riot in India.
item.dc:creator: Sam Thielman

item.title: Books Our Editors Loved This Week
item.description: Reading recommendations from critics and editors at The New York Times.

item.title: Our Favorite Hidden Gem Books of 2025
item.description: The staff of the Book Review recommends unforgettable books that made our personal best-of-the-year lists.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times Books Staff

item.title: Michael J. Fox on His Favorite Books and ‘Back to the Future’
item.description: One fiction, one nonfiction (which he turns to at night). In “Future Boy,” he recalls juggling signature roles in “Back to the Future” and “Family Ties.”
item.category: Future Boy: Back to the Future and My Journey Through the Space-Time Continuum (Book)

item.title: The Best Mystery Novels of 2025
item.description: Our columnist on the books that wowed her this year.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Weinman
item.category: Vera Wong's Guide to Snooping (on a Dead Man) (Book)

item.title: Former King Juan Carlos I of Spain, Seeking Relevance, Publishes Book
item.description: King Juan Carlos I of Spain abdicated and left for exile years ago. Now, his attempted comeback is giving his family a royal headache.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.media:description: Juan Carlos I of Spain, in February. He has been mostly left out of recent celebrations of the 50th anniversary of Spain’s transition to democracy, in which he was instrumental.

item.title: The President of the Yaddo Artist Retreat Steps Down
item.description: After a quarter century, the Yaddo president Elaina Richardson will step down, having made her mark on the storied arts residency.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
item.media:credit: Erik Tanner for The New York Times
item.media:description: In her 25 years leading Yaddo, Elaina Richardson has increased the artist residency’s endowment more than fourfold.

item.title: Sophie Kinsella, ‘Confessions of a Shopaholic’ Author, Dies at 55
item.description: Writing under a pseudonym, Madeleine Wickham cultivated an international following for her series centered on a young woman addicted to shopping.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb
item.media:credit: Sandra Mickiewicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The British author Madeleine Wickham in 2024. Under the pen name Sophie Kinsella, she wrote nine “Shopaholic” novels, which sold tens of millions of copies and were translated into dozens of languages.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Cape Fever,’ by Nadia Davids
item.description: In “Cape Fever,” a young maid finds herself dealing with ghosts from the past and a manipulative employer.
item.dc:creator: Joumana Khatib

item.title: DéLana R.A. Dameron, Writer of the Black South, Dies at 40
item.description: An award-winning poet and writer of fiction, she moonlighted as a competitive horsewoman and owned a horse farm outside Columbia, S.C.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Sea Captain’s Wife,’ by Tilar J. Mazzeo
item.description: In “The Sea Captain’s Wife,” Tilar J. Mazzeo tells the thrilling story of Mary Ann Patten, the first female captain of a merchant clipper ship.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Wright
item.media:description: Hailed by women’s rights advocates as a paragon of strength and by men as a paragon of wifely loyalty, Mary Ann Patten was “everyone’s darling,” writes the author, but away from the headlines, faced tremendous personal tragedy.

item.title: The Illustrated Children’s Book I’ll Never Stop Recommending to Adults
item.description: James Marshall’s “George and Martha” books are witty and complex in their depictions of transformative friendship.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Kingsley-Ma

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Complete Notebooks,’ by Albert Camus
item.description: The notebooks of Albert Camus, the French philosopher and novelist, have been collected in a single volume for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Dwight Garner
item.media:credit: Cecil Beaton/Condé Nast, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Albert Camus’s books explored isolation, the absurdity of existence, guilt, redemption and resilience.

item.title: Fern Michaels, Prolific Author of Romance Novels, Dies at 92
item.description: In her 40s, the self-described New Jersey housewife started building a women’s fiction empire, churning out dozens of popular books.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

item.title: Book Review: ‘Television,’ by Lauren Rothery
item.description: Lauren Rothery’s “Television” finds an action star and two writers dazed by the changing rules of the entertainment industry.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Jacobs
item.media:credit: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times

item.title: Gift-Worthy Holiday Art Books
item.description: This season’s bounty includes volumes on far-out artists, unusual cats and enviable gardens.
item.dc:creator: Leah Greenblatt

item.title: Cynthia Erivo on Her Favorite Books, “Wicked” and Her New Memoir
item.description: “I have to be still for a certain amount of time,” says the “Wicked” star and author of “Simply More: A Book for Anyone Who Has Been Told They’re Too Much.”
item.category: Simply More: A Book for Anyone Who Has Been Told They're Too Much (Book)

item.title: A Forensic Artist Brings the Protagonist of Karl Ove Knausgaard’s “The School of Night” to Life
item.description: The pair work together to envision Kristian Hadeland, the protagonist of the author’s latest novel, “The School of Night.”
item.dc:creator: Jenny Comita

item.title: Field Guides Are Getting Niche
item.description: What birders well know, fans of “composite organisms” and other creatures can now learn: how to identify obscure species in the wild.
item.dc:creator: Robert Ito
item.category: California Lizards and How to Find Them (Book)
Mosses, Liverworts & Hornworts of the World: A Guide to Every Order (Book)
The Princeton Field Guide to Sauropod and Prosauropod Dinosaurs (Book)
item.media:description: While expensive to produce, a spate of new field guides focus on unusual creatures or narrow geographic regions.
